Yeah, they say bodies but the graves they dug up where just bones. The bones weren't the issue. The fact they had no where to put the recently dead was the issue.

In (medieval??) Portugal, more specifically Évora, there were too many cemeteries and they were full. The solution? MAKE A CHAPEL COVERED IN THE BONES OF THE PEOPLE IN THE CEMETERIES. In the entrance there is a phrase that (roughly) translated reads "We the bones that were lay, for yours we wait". That's just badass. It was also made to remember man about the fragility of our mortal life. It's a must visit

shows you just how utterly insignificant your life is. Most people have no comprehension as to how many people have lived lives just as, if not more, complex as theirs. And yet 99.9% of them don't have anything in the history books about them.

Did the French cut up the dead storing them (fresh) in the catacombs?

Fun Fact: Because of the relatively oxygen poor environment and close quarters of the mass graves, the bodies did not decompose properly in the cemetaries in Paris back in the day. So when they started unearthing and moving all of those bodies to the catacombs there were these massive piles of human fat they had to get rid of. People used it to make candles and soaps. Talk about upcycling lol. From decomposing flesh to expensive Parisian candles and soaps. :)
